INTRA-AIRPORT TRANSIT
Reliability Constantly Improving
The AIRTRANS system at the Dallas/Fort Worth Airport has come
so in the history of man.
a long way since the Airport opened for the first time at 12:01 a.m.,
AIRTRANS is the first successful, fully automated transit system
January 13, 1974. On opening day, the system was operational for
in the nation. It was conceived and designed as an integral part of a
passenger service only between the terminal buildings from 7:00 a.m.
total Airport system, not as an add-on system. Today, it plays a vital
to 10:00 p.m. daily. Reliability — the likelihood that a given passenger
part in making the total Airport system work.
would find the system ready when he needed to use it — was a dismal
One component of the AIRTRANS system consists of 13 miles of
56%.
concrete guideway. It has a flat surface on which the trains ride on
Today, AIRTRANS is running 24 hours a day throughout the system
foam filled, deflation-proof tires and parapet walls on each side that
carrying passengers, employees and supplies on separate routes
help provide guidance.
and in separate trains. And reliability is better than 99% except for
There are 52 passenger trains which provide seating for 16 per-
scheduled shutdowns.
sons each plus room for 24 standees for a train capacity of 40 per-
This means there is less than a 1 percent chance that a given
sons. The train has a fiberglass body on a welded steel frame and
passenger will find the system "down" and need to use the backup
runs on a chassis not unlike that of a small bus. Half of the 52 pas-
bus service which the Airport provides in case of a breakdown.
senger trains are used for passengers and half for employees.
The Airport Board, which now operates and maintains the AIR-
There are 5 utility trains used to move supplies, etc. Each train
TRANS system, is constantly striving for the 100% reliability figure.
provides three flatbed automatic "load and unload" areas for con-
If that goal is ever attained, it will have been the first machine to do
tainerized cargo from the commissary area to the various restaurants

SnUTTIC
rarking
During holiday and peak travel periods,
all Reduced Rate Parking lots are near
capacity. Allow an additional 15 to 30
minutes to park and connect with
your flight.
When approaching DFW tune your radio
to 530 am for airport and travelers
information.
Have your parking ticket ready when
exiting the airport.
Do not lose your parking ticket. You
will be required to pay $9.00 (terminal
rate) for each day your vehicle was
parked at DFW.
Parking information 574-6772

the North and South
Reduced Rate Parking lots.
AIRTRANS stations are
located in each terminal
section at the lower level.
Follow
AIRTRANS signs
to reach your station.

South
Shuttle
Parking

D
allas/Fort Worth
International Airport
provides tours five days
a week for men's and
women's service organizations,
airport study groups, travel
agents, technically-oriented
organizations, church groups,
handicapped, mentally
retarded, hospital groups,
senior citizens, airline
personnel, and local school
groups.
Tours can be arranged to fit
the special interests of each
group. Occasionally tours are
offered for high school
students or college youths
interested in aviation careers.
The vast majority of
requests come from the local
school system, but we build
the tour around the interests
of individuals visiting the
Airport. These vary in length
and are tailored where
possible to meet the special
interest or the needs of the
persons or person touring the
Airport.
A VIP tour could be a group
of engineers from Japan,
architectural students from a
University, a head of state or
a cabinet level official.

Towr
the
Dallar/Fort Worth
Interuational
Airport

Rent Car Service
Simply follow overhead signs to auto rental
counters located near baggage claim areas. At
each counter direct phone service is available
to the four rental companies which serve DFW.
Rental car facilities are located in both the
north and south reduced rate parking areas.
It is here the actual transaction and car pickup
takes place. You may ride AIRTRANS or a
courtesy van to the rent car buildings.
You will be given a parking ticket when you
receive your car. If you leave the Airport within
one hour, there will be no charge.
There are no return facilities at the terminals.
Please take your rent car to the proper return
area. Signs along International Parkway will
direct you to these areas.
Bus and Taxi Service
Bus, limousine and taxi service to Dallas, Fort
Worth and area hotels and motels is available
at curbside near baggage claim areas at Air-
port Terminals 2E, 3E, 4E and 2W. Taxicab ser-
vice is available at all upper-level curbside exits.
Fares to downtown Dallas or Fort Worth are
about $20 (U.S.). Ground transportation be-
tween the Airport and metroplex area locations
and destinations are provided by numerous
companies. For additional ground transporta-
tion information telephone Transportation Regu-
lation at 574-5878 or 670-3161.
